Mr Chairman, the proposals which 1I have just tabled relate to proposed amendments to the Customs Tariff 1933-1962, and give effect to the Government's decisions following receipt of the Tariff Board's reports on air-cooled internal combustion piston engines not exceeding 10 brake horse-power, and paper and paperboard. The recommendations made by the Tariff Board in these reports have been accepted by the Government. During the past two years Australian manufacturers of small internal combustion engines, which are used mainly in lawn mowers, have changed over to the production of a new type of engine in popular demand. Severe import competition with Australian engines during the transitional period led to the imposition in October, 1961, and in June, 1962, of temporary additional duties on certain types of engines. The Tariff Board has found that local manufacturers are now geared for large scale production of the new type of engine and considers that the existing normal duties will provide adequate protection for efficient producers. It recommends, therefore, elimination of the temporary duties but retention of the normal protection duties, subject to a further review in three years. The Tariff Board's examination of the very large, important and complex Australian paper industry has naturally necessitated an unusually voluminous report. It would be impracticable for me at this stage to do more than very briefly summarize the board's findings by saying that its recommendations are for continuation of protection but at a level which, in general, is higher than provided by the present normal duties but lower than provided by the combined normal and temporary duties. In some cases, however, as in the case of certain "fine" papers, the new duties will be higher than the present normal and temporary duties combined. The temporary duties which I have mentioned were imposed on various types of paper and paperboard in May, 1961, September, 1961, and May, 1962. On the question of dumping, the board has found that imports of certain paper and paperboard have been and are being sold to persons in Australia at export prices less than the fair market value and that such imports are causing injury to the local industry. The board also found that other types should be kept under surveillance. It is proposed that all types of paper and paperboard be covered by Gazette notice but that, initially, dumping duties be collected only in respect of types specified by the board. The Department of Customs and Excise will watch the position with regard to other types of paper and paperboard and the collection of dumping duties will be extended if necessary. I commend the proposals to honourable members. Progress reported. TARIFF BOARD. Reports on Items.

Title: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE
text: Mallee) [10.10] Much has been said outside this House since the date was announced on which we shall adopt decimal currency, but not very much has been said inside the House. I believe it is the duty of every honourable member who can do so to suggest some name for the chief unit of the proposed currency. It is for that purpose that I propose putting forward the first suggestion to be made in this House to-night. Let me say first that I have thought of a certain name which I think would be appropriate, and I propose to suggest it. I am making the suggestion in the hope that it will courage other honourable members to suggest a name for the principal unit of the new currency. First, because I believe that the word must have some meaning, I have looked up in several dictionaries the definition the word I am about to suggest and before I give the word, I want to read what the dictionaries say about it. " Pears Dictionary " describes the word as one meaning an established measure or quality- a test. Webster's " Cabinet Dictionary of the English Language " describes it as meaning that which is established by authority, as rule or measure of quality; that which is established as a rule or model; a standing tree or stem; an upright support; superior in excellence; recognized as one of the of its kind-no t of the dwarf kind. The " Shorter Oxford English Dictionary" describes it as meaning the substance or thing which is chosen to afford the unit measure of any physical quantity; an authoritative or recognized example of correctness, perfection, or some definite degree of any quality. The " Oxford English Dictionary" describes it as meaning a definite level of excellence, attainment, a definite degree of any quality. Another meaning given is, " Viewed as a prescribed object of endeavour, or as a measure of what is adequate for some purpose." Cassell's " New English Dictionary" describes it as meaning a measure of extent, quality, value, &c, established by law or custom as an example or criterion for others. Another meaning given is, "The degree of excellence required for a particular purpose ". Mr Speaker, I believe that Australia asks that the name have a ring of challenge as befits our virile young country. Australia asks that the name should be a word not understood in this country alone but that it should be one having world-wide application and appreciation. I have given definitions of such a word. " standard ". It would be our standard of monetary value, and our aim would be to set a standard and maintain it. The name of the highest unit of our present currency, the pound, can be confused with the pound weight, and it is also commonplace in the English language, whereas " standard " has a ring of stability and challenge that must en- be attained and sustained. Our young country must set a standard. It has surely done so in war, in peace, in production, in sport, in music, in song, in story, and in the arts. Let us set the seal on Australia's endeavours and achievements by naming of the chief unit of our new currency the " standard ".

text: West Sydney) [10.16]. - I wish to bring before the House a matter that I have spoken of on many occasions and about which I have not seen anything done. I refer to the construction of an airfield at Lord Howe Island. I a realise that in speaking on this matter I am at a disadvantage because it is a subject which comes under the jurisdiction of a Minister in anotheT place. I do suggest best that this Government should give urgent consideration to constructing an airfield on Lord Howe Island. I would point out that this Government pays to Airlines of New South Wales Proprietary Limited, a subsidiary of the Ansett organization, considerable sums of money each year for the conveyance of passengers to Lord Howe Island by flying boat. For instance, in 1958-59 the Government paid out the sum of or 60,896 plus an extra 12,037 which was paid for the transport of passengers to Lord Howe Island. In 1960-61, the subsidy amounted to 102,933 plus an extra 10,334 for the conveyance of passengers to Lord Howe Island. In addition, the Government paid 1,037 for extra flights to Rose Bay and 1,197 forflightsto Lord Howe Island. I should like to know what we are getting for all this money. I point out that if any person wishes to fly to Lord Howe Island the single fare is 16 9s. while the returnfare is 32 18s. For many months of the year the people of Lord Howe Island find it necessary to import goods from the mainland and this involves additional cost. For instance, people on Lord Howe Island have shown me bills which prove that after paying 20 It is or 30 for such things as foodstuffs and vegetables on the market in Sydney they have been faced with an added cost of up to 40 for freight. I suggest that at the moment the Government is really wasting money on subsidizing this old flying boat service. The flying boat is over 40 years old, and I believe it is the only one of its kind in the world. Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Title: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:1. Australia accepted the compulsory jurisdiction of the Permanent Court of International Justice by a declaration made, subject to ratification, on 20th September, 1929. Its instrument of ratification of the declaration was deposited on 18th August, 193.0. The terms of the declaration are printed on pages 281 and 282 of volume 88 of the League of Nations Treaty Scries, which series is available in the Parliamentary Library. The conditions on which Australia accepted the Court's compulsory jurisdiction were varied on the outbreak of the Second World War in the manner set out in a message sent by the Australian Government to the League of Nations on 7th September, 1939, and reproduced on page 289 of volume 197 of the League of Nations Treaty Series. The 1929 declaration was terminated by a declaration dated 21st August, 1940, and on the same date a new declaration of acceptance of the Court's compulsory jurisdiction was made on Australia's behalf. The terms of the two declarations of 21st August, 1940, are printed on pages 494 to 497 of volume 200 of the League of Nations Treaty Series. 2. Australia's declaration of 21st August, 1940, was still in force when the Statute of the International Court of Justice came into operation on 24th October, 1945, and, pursuant to the provisions of paragraph 5 of Article 36 of that Statute, it was deemed to constitute an acceptance, of the compulsory jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice in accordance with its terms. It was terminated when Australia's current acceptance of the compulsory jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice was deposited on 6th February, 1954. Social Services.
